Does anyone know if there’s a way to retain semantic markup in the Rich Text module/Rich Text fields when using custom fonts in a theme?

When using a default font, or one available via Google Fonts, functionality like Bold and Italic use semantic markup — they’ll add a `<strong>` or `<em>` tag, respectively. However, in my themes which use custom fonts, the bold and italic buttons are disabled entirely; the only way to change slant and weight variants is via the font dropdown. This means that all changes to font styling are applied using the style attribute on `<span>`s, which poses a few issues:

1. Any sort of emphasis or differentiation applied to text is rendered completely invisible to assistive technology and other non-sight-based methods of interaction. While it won’t completely inhibit the usage of a site, this still unquestionably provides a degraded and *less complete experience for users of assistive technologies.*
2. It provides a *significantly worse editor experience*. Editors are no longer able to use the familiar Ctrl+B/Ctrl+I shortcuts for formatting text — instead, they have to select it from the “Change font” menu, which is a whole mess of its own. _(unintuitive relocation of core editing functionality, buggy and disordered selection flyouts, improper font rendering — I could go on.)_
3. It complicates font handling and typesetting from a development standpoint, since it basically goes bull-in-china-shop on any styling we’ve defined, inserts excessive and messy markup, and is messy/inconsistent to target via CSS or JS.
As it stands, the best workaround I’ve identified is to avoid using any built-in custom font functionality, and to instead use a standard `@font-face` import. This re-enables bold and italic functionality, but comes with its own set of editor experience drawbacks.

It seems like this is just a hard-and-fast limitation, but I’m double-checking to be sure I’m not missing some obscure documentation page or undocumented feature/restriction.
